comment: Developing and attacking the pawn.
Philidor's Defense. Black usually ends up with a cramped position. More usual is 2... Nc6
Taking possession of the center and threatening the pawn on e5 again.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4
comment: Indirectly protecting the pawn. However, Black will be forced to trade this powerful bishop for the knight and give White a lead in development.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5
comment: If 4... dxe5 then 5. Qxd8+ Kxd8 6. Nxe5 wins a pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4
comment: Threatening 7. Qxf7#. Black's best here is 6... Qe7 although since Qe7 blocks the bishop on f8, White would have a huge positional advantage.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6
comment: This looks like a logical move; however, it quickly leads to a losing position.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3
comment: Threatening 8. Bxf7+

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7
comment: White could win a rook for a knight with 8. Bxf7+ Qxf7 9. Qxb7. An immediate 8. Qxb7 does not win the rook because of 8... Qb4+ exchanging queens.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3
comment: White decides that simple development is even stronger than 8. Bxf7+. White's superior development combined with Black's awkwardly placed pieces gives White an overwhelming positional advantage.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6
comment: Protecting the pawn on b7 with the queen and guarding d5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5
comment: A powerful pin.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5
comment: This loses at once, but Black wouldn't have been able to hold out much longer with any move.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5 10. Nxb5
comment: Beginning an eloquent combination.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5 10. Nxb5 cxb5 11. Bxb5+
comment: If 11... Kd8 then 12. Bxf6 Qxf6 13. Qd5+ Qd6 14. Qxa8 wins.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5 10. Nxb5 cxb5 11. Bxb5+ Nbd7 12. O-O-O
comment: Threatening 13. Bxf6 gxf6 14. Bxd7+. Notice how all White's pieces are developed and working together.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5 10. Nxb5 cxb5 11. Bxb5+ Nbd7 12. O-O-O Rd8 13. Rxd7
comment: The end is near.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5 10. Nxb5 cxb5 11. Bxb5+ Nbd7 12. O-O-O Rd8 13. Rxd7 Rxd7 14. Rd1
comment: The pinned rook is doomed. White threatens 15. Bxd7+ and 15... Nxd7 could not be played because the knight is pinned.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5 10. Nxb5 cxb5 11. Bxb5+ Nbd7 12. O-O-O Rd8 13. Rxd7 Rxd7 14. Rd1 Qe6
comment: This unpins the knight. White could win material now with 16. Bxf6, but, instead, plays a combination that puts this game into the history books.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5 10. Nxb5 cxb5 11. Bxb5+ Nbd7 12. O-O-O Rd8 13. Rxd7 Rxd7 14. Rd1 Qe6 15. Bxd7+ Nxd7
comment: Is everything protected?

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Bg4 4. dxe5 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 dxe5 6. Bc4 Nf6 7. Qb3 Qe7 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bg5 b5 10. Nxb5 cxb5 11. Bxb5+ Nbd7 12. O-O-O Rd8 13. Rxd7 Rxd7 14. Rd1 Qe6 15. Bxd7+ Nxd7 16. Qb8+
comment: Everything but the king.
